questions.text: A 3 year old male patient presented with skin lesions and crusting. What kind of organism caused this lesion?
questions.solution:
• Given lesion in the image shows honey coloured crust around mouth in preschool age suggestive of Impetigo.
  • Causative organisms are gram positive cocci-streptococcus and staphylococcus aureus.
  • Preschool and young school-age children are most often affected.
  • Non bullous impetigo may be caused by both S. aureus and streptococcal bacteria. Bullous impetigo is a superficial cutaneous infection with S. aureus
  • In non bullous impetigo, The exuding serum dries to form yellowish brown crusts
  • The face especially around the nose and mouth and the limbs are the sites most commonly affected.

Option B, C & D : Impetigo is caused by Staphylococcus and streptococci which are Gram Positive Cocci.

Key Takeaway:

Impetigo, which is caused by gram-positive cocci, specifically Streptococcus and Staphylococcus aureus. Common in preschool and young school-age children, presenting with honey-colored crusts, particularly around the mouth and nose.

questions.text: A patient presented with hypo-pigmented macules over back and upper trunk, on KOH mount spaghetti and meat ball appearance was seen. What can be the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The case given here is Pityriasis versicolor. Causative agent is Malasezzia globosa/ M. furfur

Clinical lesions are hypo or hyperpigmented macules over neck, chest ,upper back.

Scratch sign- positive

On KOH mount- Yeast and hyphae are seen known as 'spaghetti and meatball appearance'

On wood's lamp: Pale yellow fluorescence

Treatment: Azoles, selenium sulfide

Option A : Trichophyton sp. Causes dermatophyte infection- Tinea cruris, Tinea corporis, Onychomycosis.

Option B : Candida sp causes intertrigo, oral candidiasis, Onychomycosis

Option D : Hortaea werneckii is a causative agent of tinea nigra.

Key Takeaway :

Pityriasis Versicolor :

  • Due to Malazzeia Globosa / Furfur
  • O/E - Hypo / Hyperpigmented macules
  • Spaghetti & Meatball appearance on KOH
  • Rx with Azores & Selenium Sulfide.

questions.text: A 50 year old diabetic patient presented with a complaint of burning in mouth. On examination, there were white lesions in the oral cavity as shown in the image. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Oral candidiasis is a fungal infection of the mouth often called 'thrush

Causative agent- Candida sp.

Predisposing factor- Diabetes, Immunocompromised state, HIV

Candida pseudomembranes are sometimes described as "curdled milk" or "cottage cheese" appearance.

Option B :

Aphthous ulcer usually begins as a round yellowish elevated spot surrounded by a red halo. This then breaks down into a punched-out ulcer, which is covered with a loosely attached white, yellow, or grayish membrane.

Option C :

Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune disease with oral erosion usually associated with cutaneous vesiculobullous lesions.

Option D :

Oral lichen planus is white streaks in a lacy or fern-like pattern in oral mucosa. It is associated with skin lesions and nail changes.

Key Takeaway:

Candida Infectious occurs mostly in Immunocompromised & DM patient Giving Whitish Cottage Cheese Appearance.

questions.text: Identify the image given associated with scaling and itching.
questions.solution:
The image is of tinea corporis.

Patient presents with annular erythematous itchy lesions with scaling. The lesion shows active margins and central clearing.

Option B -

Granuloma annulare (GA) is a common inflammatory skin condition typified clinically by annular, smooth, discolored papules and plaques.

Option C -

Pyoderma gangrenosum (PG) is a rare noninfectious neutrophilic dermatosis. Clinically it starts with sterile pustules that rapidly progress and turn into painful ulcers of variable depth and size with undermined violaceous borders. The legs are most commonly affected.

Option D -

Ichthyosis is a group of skin diseases that causes extremely dry, thick, and scaly skin. The skin often looks like it has fish scales.

Key Takeaway:

Annular Erythematous Lesions Ddx

  1. Clearing - Tinea
  2. Crusting - Leishmaniasis
  3. Scarring - Lupus Vulgaris

questions.text: Antifungal with anti-inflammatory and antipruritic Action?
questions.solution:
Therapeutic antifungal agents with Antiinflammatory activity-

Ciclopirox olamine, butoconazole, sertaconazole.

In addition, they have anti pruritic activity by inhibiting cytokine release.

Key Takeaway:

Therapeutic antifungal agents with Antiinflammatory activity- Ciclopirox olamine, butoconazole, sertaconazole.

questions.text: A 40 year old male farmer presented with growth as shown below. There was a history of penetrating trauma. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Chromoblastomycosis (Verrucous dermatitis)

Causative agent: Pigmented (Dematiaceous fungi)

  • Fonsecaea pedrosoi
  • Phialophora verrucosa

Clinical feature:

Rough warty, cauliflower like lesions over exposed (trauma prone) sites . MC on foot.

Histopathology shows medlar / sclerotic bodies/ copper penny bodies.

Treatment: Itraconazole

Option A:

Sporotrichosis (Rose gardener's disease/ rose thorn disease)

Causative agent: Sporothrix schenckii

It is dimorphic fungus

There are 3 types:

KOH mount: cigar shaped yeast

Histopathology shows 'Asteroid bodies'

Option C:

Mycetoma

Madura foot also known as Mycetoma, an uncommon chronic infection of skin and subcutaneous tissues in tropical countries is caused by true fungi (eumycetoma) or by filamentous bacteria (actinomycetoma).

It is characterized by the triad of

  • Painless firm mass
  • Multiple sinus
  • Purulent discharge containing grains

Option D:

Warts are Pointed Papule & Plaque Like Lesion caused by HPV 6,11 Strains.

Key Takeaway:

Chromoblastomycosis

  • Fonsecaea pedrosoi
  • Cauliflower Like Lesions on foot with Medlar / Sclerotic Bodies on Histopathology.
  • Rx - Itraconazole

questions.text: A farmer presented with the following swelling on foot with discharging sinus. Stain from the lesion showed gram positive filamentous structure. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Madura foot also known as Mycetoma, an uncommon chronic infection of skin and subcutaneous tissues in tropical countries is caused by true fungi (eumycetoma) or by filamentous bacteria (actinomycetoma).

It is characterized by the triad of

  • Painless firm mass
  • Multiple sinus
  • Purulent discharge containing grains

Actinomycetoma is caused by Gram positive filamentous bacteria . Here Nocardia brasiliensis is the correct answer.

Option B: Sporotrichosis, also known as "Rose Gardener's Disease," is a subacute or chronic infection caused by the saprophytic dimorphic fungus Sporothrix schenckii. The characteristic infection involves suppurating subcutaneous nodules that progress proximally along lymphatic channels

Option C :

Staphylococcus aureus causes Botryomycosis. It is a chronic suppurative granulomatous bacterial infection. Lesion is composed of mass of fibrous tissue, draining pus and sinus tracts.On stain, Gram positive cocci are seen

Option D : Aspergillus is a fungus causing Eumycetoma. Here lesions show gram positive filamentous structure thus aspergillus is ruled out.

Key takeaway:

  • Mycetoma due to true fungi (eumycetoma) or by filamentous bacteria (actinomycetoma).
  • Triad of Painless firm mass + Multiple sinus + Purulent discharge containing sulfur grains.

questions.text: A patient has a history of thorn prick while working in the garden, the lesion spread linearly up till shoulder. What will be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Sporotrichosis (Rose gardener's disease/ rose thorn disease)

Causative agent: Sporothrix schenckii

It is dimorphic fungus

There are 3 types:

KOH mount: Cigar shaped yeast

Histopathology shows 'Asteroid bodies'

Option A:

Skin abscesses are collections of pus in the dermis and adipose tissue that usually result from infection.

Option B:

A furuncle (or boil) is an acute, usually necrotic, infection of a hair follicle with S. aureus

Option D:

Lymphedema is a chronic disease marked by the increased collection of lymphatic fluid in the body, causing swelling.

Key Takeaway:

Sporotrichosis

  • Due to Sporotrichum Schenckii Dimorphic Fungus
  • 3 Forms : Cutaneous, Lymphatic & Systemic
  • KOH - Cigar Shaped yeast
  • Histopath - Asteroid Bodies

questions.text: Which drug can be given as a nail lacquer in treatment of onychomycosis?
questions.solution:
Onychomycosis, a fungal infection of the nails, can be treated with topical antifungal agents like amorolfine and ciclopirox olamine. These agents are typically applied as nail lacquers.

Advantages of Nail Lacquers:

  • Better penetration: Both amorolfine 5% and ciclopirox olamine 8% lacquers offer improved penetration through the nail plate, enhancing their effectiveness.
  • Keratin structure: Traditional forms like creams or ointments struggle to penetrate the nail keratin structure, making them less suitable for onychomycosis treatment.

Mechanism of Action:

  • Amorolfine: Inhibits the production of ergosterol, a vital component of the fungal cell membrane, leading to fungal cell death.

Dosage:

  • Amorolfine nail lacquer 5%: Apply once a week.
  • Ciclopirox olamine nail lacquer 8%: Apply daily.

Option A, B & D : Naftifine, Nystatin & Flucytosine are topical Antifungal not useful in onychomycosis.

Key takeaway :

Amorolfine nail lacquer and ciclopirox olamine nail lacquer are used in onychomycosis.Ciclopirox 8% and amorolfine 5% lacquers provide better penetration of active substances through the nail plate and thus increase effectiveness of the agent.

questions.text: A HIV positive adult male presented with hilar lymphadenopathy and lung involvement presented with lesions on face as shown. CBNAAT was negative. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Histoplasmosis is a fungal infection caused by the Histoplasma capsulatum. It often presents with

  • Skin lesions shows Papules with central umbilication
  • Pulmonary symptoms and hilar lymphadenopathy, especially in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with HIV.

Negative CBNAAT (which is specific for tuberculosis) further supports this diagnosis.

Umbilicated Lesions-

1. Infections

Viral: Mollscum contagiosum (MC)→

Fungal

  • Disseminated cryptococcosis in HIV
  • Histoplasmosis
  • Penicilliosis.

Bacterial: Histoid leprosy

2. Tumors

  • Keratoacanthoma
  • Basal cell carcinoma

Option B: Molluscum contagiosum:
Molluscum contagiosum is a viral infection that presents with small, dome-shaped lesions on the skin but typically does not cause hilar lymphadenopathy or lung involvement.

Option C: Cryptococcosis:
Cryptococcosis, caused by Cryptococcus neoformans, can cause lung involvement and is often associated with meningitis in HIV patients,

Option D: Disseminated tuberculosis:
Disseminated tuberculosis can cause lung involvement and lymphadenopathy; however, the CBNAAT being negative makes this diagnosis less likely. In addition, TB skin lesions typically present differently from those associated with histoplasmosis.

Key Takeaway:

Papule with central umbilication

Molluscum contagiosum- Only skin

Histoplasmosis- Skin + Lung involvement

Cryptococcosis- Skin + Meningitis

questions.text: A 48 year old female patient presented with burning pain associated with fluid filled lesions over right shoulder. What will be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Painful vesicles in a grouped manner in dermatomal distribution is suggestive of Herpes zoster.

Herpes Zoster :

  • Reactivation of varicella.
  • Eruptive phase lesions : Unilateral
  • Dermatomal, Painful grouped vesicles over red base.
  • Complication : Post herpetic neuralgia (allodynia is seen).

Option A: Molluscum contagiosum present as asymptomatic white to skin colored umbilicated small papules.

Option C: Chicken pox present as fever with polymorphic lesions over erythematous base over trunk (Dew drop on rose petal appearance).

Option D: Herpes simplex is not related to dermatomal distribution. usually present as vesicles or crust around lips and oral erosions. Or it can present as genital erosions.

Key Takeaway:

Zoster:

  • Reactivation of varicella.
  • Eruptive phase lesions : Unilateral
  • Dermatomal, Painful grouped vesicles over red base.
  • Complication : Post herpetic neuralgia (allodynia is seen).

questions.text: A patient presented to the opd with the lesions as shown in the figure. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Herpes labialis is caused by HSV-1.

Patient presents with grouped vesicles around the lips Associated with fever.

Tzanck smear shows multinucleated giant cells.

Treatment: T. Acyclovir 400mg TDS for 7 days.

Option B : Impetigo is a common infection that is highly contagious and most commonly caused by gram-positive bacteria. It most commonly presents as a honey colored crust. Impetigo is a disease of children who reside in hot humid climates. Group A β-hemolytic Streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes) represents an important cause of non-bullous impetigo. It can lead to Post streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

Option C : Pemphigus vulgaris autoimmune bullous disease. Characterized by oral and genital erosion with fluid filled lesions (Vesicles and bulla) over skin which rutire to form erosions and crusting.

Option D : Chickenpox is a highly contagious viral infection that causes an acute fever and rash, mainly in children. Chickenpox is also known as varicella. Caused by varicella zoster virus, of the Herpesviridae family. Also called herpesvirus type 3.Lesions of chicken pox are polymorphic in nature (different morphology). Lesion starts as a papule which then becomes a vesicle with erythematous base. Then the vesicle ruptures to form crusting.

Key Takeaway:

  • Herpes Labialis
  • Caused by HSV-1.
  • Present with grouped vesicles around the lips.
  • Tzanck smear shows multinucleated giant cells.
  • Treatment : T. Acyclovir 400mg TDS for 7 days.

questions.text: A 5 year old child presents with a generalized vesicular eruption all over the body involving the trunk. His brother also had a similar rash. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Varicella:

Morphology: Crops of papules with erythematous halo; rapidly become vesicular (dew drops on rose petal appearance), then pustular.

Eruption at different stages present.

Heal with minimal scarring unless complicated by secondary infection or hemorrhagic lesions (as seen in immunocompromised).

Adults usually have a more severe eruption.

Site: Centripetal distribution.

Prophylaxis: Live attenuated vaccine.

Treatment: Specific antiviral therapy (acyclovir 800mg, five times daily × 7–10 days) in adults and in immunocompromised individuals. None needed in children.

Option B:

Rubella is a viral disease characterized by rash, swollen glands and fever. Mucosal involvement results in the Forchheimer sign, in which pinpoint or larger petechiae are noted on the soft palate and uvula during the prodromal period of rubella.Rash begins on the face that spreads to the neck, trunk and extremities. Appear as erythematous papules about 2-3 mm in size.

Option C:

Measles Presents as fever, malaise, and loss of appetite, followed by conjunctivitis, cough, and coryza. In the Prodromal phase, Koplik spots appear. These are blue-white spots on the inside of the mouth opposite the molars. Erythematous macules ranging from 0.1-1.0cm in diameter appear on the 4th or 5th day following the start of symptoms. This non-itchy rash begins on the face and behind the ears. Within 24-36 hours it spreads over the entire trunk and extremities (palms and soles rarely involved)

Option D:

Mumps Infection typically presents with a prodrome of headache, fever, fatigue, anorexia, malaise followed by the classic hallmark of the disease, parotitis.

Key Takeaway:

Varicella:

  • Etiology : Varicella zoster.
  • Period of infectivity : Until all lesions crust.
  • Lesion : Dew drop on rose petal appearance.
  • Pleomorphic rash
  • Site : Trunk (Centripetal distribution).

questions.text: Child with complaints of fever neck rigidity with associated oral erosions & skin manifestations as shown in the pics. CSF analysis shows normal glucose, Proteins & lymphocytes elevated. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
CSF findings in this case are suggestive of viral meningitis.

Skin manifestations given in image are erythema multiforme over the palm and multiple grouped vesicles near the mouth suggest herpes virus infection.

Herpes simplex infection can present with-

  • Herpes labialis
  • Herpetic gingivostomatitis
  • Erythema multiforme
  • Encephalitis
  • Eczema herpeticum

Meningitis Ddx:

Option A: Hand foot mouth disease does not manifest as meningitis

Option C: CSF findings in this case are suggestive of viral meningitis. So Bacterial Meningitis Ruled out.

Option D: CSF findings in this case are suggestive of viral meningitis. So TB Meningitis Ruled Out.

Key Takeaway:

Viral Meningitis Findings :

  • Clear CSF
  • Normal Glucose
  • Lymphocyte elevated

questions.text: A child presents with sores in the mouth and a rash on the hands and feet as shown in the image below. What is the causative organism for it?
questions.solution:
The case given here is Hand foot and mouth disease . Causative agents are Coxsackievirus A16 virus and enterovirus 71. It Presents with Vesicular lesions on palms & soles, buttocks & oral cavity.

Option B: Pox virus causes molluscum contagiosum, present with asymptomatic papules with central umbilication.

Option C: Herpes virus manifests as

  • Herpes labialis
  • Herpetic gingivostomatitis
  • Erythema multiforme
  • Encephalitis
  • Eczema herpeticum

Option D: HPV virus manifest as Anogenital warts.

Key Takeaway:

Hand Foot Mouth disease :

  • Etiology : Coxsackie A16, Enterovirus 71.
  • Vesicular lesions on palms & soles, buttocks & oral cavity.

questions.text: HPV protein used in vaccine targeted against HPV is-
questions.solution:
HPV vaccine contains inactive L1 protein which is Major capsid Protein of HPV.

HPV vaccine can be given to both females and males

Age group - 9 to 26 years

<15 years - 2 doses ( 0 and 6 months)

>15 years - 3 disease ( 0 , 2 and 6 months)

Cervarix (HPV 16 and 18)

Gardasil (HPV 6, 11, 16 and 18)

Gardasil 9 (HPV 6,11,16,18,31,33,45,52, 58)

Option A : E6/E7 Protein Causes Cancer by Blocking P53 & RB Gene Functions Respectively.

Option C : E1/E2 Protein Helps in Replication & Transcription.

Option D : L2 is Minor Capsid Protein.

HPV Proteins:

Key Takeaway:

HPV vaccine contains inactive L1 protein which is Major capsid Protein of HPV.

questions.text: A 21 year old male patient, resident of bihar, presented with 2 years of history of gradually increasing multiple hypopigmented lesions on the trunk, upper extremities, and face. Sensation and nerve examination was normal. He did not respond to antibiotics, antifungal or steroids. Slit skin smear was negative for acid fast bacilli. What will be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Post kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis (PKDL) is a skin condition that occurs following visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar). It is characterized by hypopigmented patches, which can also appear as erythematous plaques and nodules, particularly on the face and upper body. The key points leading to this diagnosis include:

  • Geographical Endemicity: PKDL is endemic in regions like India, Nepal, and Bangladesh.
  • Clinical Presentation: The gradual increase in hypopigmented lesions aligns with PKDL, which manifests after initial recovery from kala-azar.
  • Negative Slit Skin Smear: The absence of acid-fast bacilli rules out leprosy and supports the diagnosis of PKDL, as it does not involve mycobacterial infection.

Option A: Pityriasis versicolor: This fungal infection typically presents with scaly macules that can show both hyper- and hypopigmentation, particularly in sun-exposed areas. It would usually respond to antifungal treatment, which this patient did not.

Option B: Lepromatous leprosy: Patients typically present with sensory loss, skin nodules, and nasal symptoms. The presence of hypopigmented lesions alone and a negative smear make leprosy unlikely.

Option D: Vitiligo vulgaris: This condition involves loss of skin pigmentation but is usually more stable and does not respond to antifungals or antibiotics. It also does not fit the patient's history of prior visceral leishmaniasis.

Key Takeaway

Post kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis (PKDL) is the likely diagnosis for this patient, characterized by gradually increasing hypopigmented lesions on the trunk, upper extremities, and face, occurring after recovery from visceral leishmaniasis.

The negative slit skin smear for acid-fast bacilli further supports this diagnosis, ruling out conditions like leprosy and indicating a non-mycobacterial cause.

questions.text: Which layer of skin is involved in the image shown below?
questions.solution:
The given image comes under the category special lesions known as Burrow lesion

The given image comes under the category of special lesions known as Burrow lesions. These lesions are characteristic features of Scabies. Caused by the infestation of the mite Sarcoptes Scabiei

Usually seen in the-

  • Web spaces
  • Flexors of wrist, elbow & axilla
  • Periareolar area
  • Peri umbilical area
  • Groin

Forming a circle known as "Circle Hebra"

Stratum corneum

Topmost layer of epidermis with dead keratinocytes. These cells don't contain a nucleus. Hence, mitotic/metabolic activity is absent. These are Flat & dehydrated cells

It forms a barrier that is directly involved in visible skin lesions like Burrow lesions in scabies.

Option A: Stratum Basale (stratum germinativum)

  • Deepest layer of the epidermis is Stratum Basale

Option C: Stratum granulosum (Granular Cell Layer)

  • Synthesize Lipids which forms a protective barrier

Option D: Subcutaneous Layer (hypodermis)

  • This layer consists of fat and connective tissue. It supports and insulates the skin but does not feature in surface lesions.

Key Takeaway :

  • Burrow Lesions: Characteristic of scabies; they indicate the presence of mites in the skin.
  • Stratum Corneum Role: This layer is crucial for barrier function and is where many visible skin conditions manifest.
  • Affected Areas: Common sites include web spaces, flexures, and areas around the umbilicus and groin, illustrating the distribution pattern of scabies lesions.

questions.text: Identify the arthropod shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Human scabies is a contagious skin condition caused by infestation with the human itch mite (Sarcoptes scabiei var. hominis). These microscopic mites burrow into the upper layer of the skin, where they lay eggs and reproduce.

Life Cycle Stages:

  1. Egg: Laid by the female mite in burrows.
  2. Larva: Hatches from the egg and emerges from the burrow.
  3. Nymph: Immature stage of the mite.
  4. Adult: Mature mite that reproduces and lays eggs.

Key Features:

  • Incubation period: Typically 4 weeks between infestation and the appearance of symptoms.
  • Number of mites: Most people have 10-15 mites. In severe cases (Norwegian scabies), millions of mites can be present.

Scabies is highly contagious and spreads easily through close skin-to-skin contact. Treatment involves medications to kill the mites and relieve itching. It's important to treat all members of a household to prevent re-infestation.

Option A: Pediculus humanus capitis (head louse) causes pediculosis capitis.

Option C: Pthirus pubis causes pediculosis pubis. Maculae ceruleae' is a bluish macule occurring at the site of pthirus pubis bite.

Option D- Dermatobia hominis Known as the human botfly, this parasite causes myiasis, where the larvae infest the skin but do not burrow like scabies mites.

Key Takeaway :

Human scabies is a contagious skin condition caused by infestation with the human itch mite (Sarcoptes scabiei var. hominis). These microscopic mites burrow into the upper layer of the skin, where they lay eggs and reproduce.

questions.text: A patient presents with pruritus of the interdigital spaces of the left hand. Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
• Scabies is caused by the mite Sarcoptes scabiei, leading to intense itching, especially in the web spaces between fingers and other flexural areas (often referred to as the "Circle of Hebra").
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Multiple excoriated erythematous papules in the interdigital spaces.
    • Itching is often worse at night.
    • Scabies is highly contagious, spreading through direct, prolonged skin-to-skin contact.

Option B. Dermatitis herpetiformis: Typically presents with vesicular lesions on extensor surfaces and is associated with gluten sensitivity, not specifically with interdigital pruritus.

Option C. Xerotic dermatitis: Usually manifests as dry, scaly patches that can be itchy but typically does not localize to interdigital spaces.

Option D. Erythema multiforme: Characterized by target lesions and is often associated with infections or drug reactions; it does not typically present with isolated itching in interdigital areas.

Key Takeaways:

  • Scabies is characterized by intense itching and the specific location of lesions in the web spaces of the fingers and flexors.
  • Highly contagious
  • Night aggravation
  • Treatment options include topical permethrin, crotamiton, and systemic ivermectin.

questions.text: Which of the following presents with an infestation of eyelash?
questions.solution:
Pthirus Pubis (Pubic Lice)

Pthirus pubis, also known as pubic lice, are parasitic insects that infest the hair in the pubic region. They can also spread to other areas with coarse hair, including the armpits, eyelashes, and eyebrows.

Key Features:

  • Infestation: Live and feed on blood from the host.
  • Symptoms: Intense itching, irritation, and visible lice or nits (eggs) in the hair.
  • Transmission: Spread through close sexual contact or sharing personal items like clothing or bedding.

Treatment for pubic lice typically involves medications that kill the lice and their eggs. It's important to treat all sexual partners to prevent re-infestation.

Option A- Pediculosis capitis

  • Refers to an infestation of the scalp with head lice. These lice primarily inhabit the hair on the head and do not infest eyelashes.

Option B- Pediculosis corporis

  • This involves body lice (Pediculus humanus corporis) that live on clothing and only move to the skin to feed. They do not infest eyelashes.

Option D- Hymenoptera

  • This refers to an order of insects that includes bees, wasps, and ants. They do not cause infestations in hair or eyelashes.

Key Takeaway:

  • Pthirus pubis: The causative agent of pubic lice, known for infesting coarse hair, including eyelashes.
  • Distinct Infestations: Other lice types (pediculosis capitis and corporis) have specific habitats and do not infest eyelashes.

questions.text: Vagabond's disease is:
questions.solution:
Vagabond's disease is a synonym for pediculosis corporis, a condition caused by an infestation of body lice. It is often associated with homelessness or lack of access to adequate hygiene.

  • Cause: Infestation with body lice (Pediculus humanus corporis).
  • Symptoms: Intense itching, especially in the areas where lice are present (typically the seams of clothing).
  • Risk Factors: Homelessness, poor hygiene, overcrowding.
  • Transmission: Spread through close contact with an infected person or sharing contaminated clothing or bedding.
  • Treatment: Topical medications to kill the lice and their eggs.

Option A- Extensive tinea corporis

  • This refers to a fungal infection of the skin (ringworm) that can cover large areas of the body. It does not relate to infestations or 'vagabond's disease.'

Option B- Scabies

  • Caused by the mite Sarcoptes scabiei, scabies leads to intense itching and skin lesions but is not referred to as vagabond’s disease.

Option D- Pediculosis Capitis

  • This refers to head lice infestations (Pediculus humanus capitis), which primarily affect the scalp and hair. It is not related to vagabond’s disease.

Key Takeaway :

  • Vagabond's Disease: Another name for pediculosis corporis, linked to body lice infestations.
  • Population at Risk: Commonly seen in individuals with inadequate hygiene, often in crowded or impoverished settings.
